column1: #Text=[0029] high power consumption when it is running continuously;
#Text=[0030] potential threat to personal privacy by reconstructing the sampled raw data.
#Text=[0031] Voice command recognition has progressed in paralleled with the development of automatic speech recognition.

#Text=Most digital based solution using a high-speed and high resolution ADC extract the features in the frequency domain like Mel-frequency cepstrum coefficients (MFCC), Linear Predictive Coding (LPC), etc.
#Text=Statistical Hidden Markov Models (HMM) are then used to model the phonemes or words.
#Text=Disadvantages of this solution include high computation complexity and power consumption.
#Text=[0032] FIG. 1 is an illustration of a device in which detection of a unique sound may be used to cause the system to perform a task or operation.
#Text=In this example, a person 100 may be interacting with a mobile phone 120.

#Text=System user 100 may be holding the cell phone and talking directly to it, or user 100 may be wearing an earpiece 110 that contains a microphone and detection circuitry and is in contact with mobile phone 120 via a Bluetooth wireless channel, for example.
#Text=In either case, earphone 110 and/or phone 120 may often be placed in a low power state in order to conserve battery power.

#Text=Occasionally, user 100 may wish to place a call or otherwise interact with phone 120 and may speak a known word or phrase, such as "hello", or "call", or any other word or phrase that device 110 or 120 has been configured to expect.
#Text=Sound energy in the form of a sound wave 102 may be received by a microphone within earpiece 110 or phone 120 and converted to an analog electrical signal.

#Text=However, in order for earpiece 110 or phone 120 to respond to a known voice command from user 100, some portion of detection logic must be powered on to determine when an expected voice command is received.

#Text=Since user 100 may speak a large number of words and phrases that have nothing to do with earpiece 110 and/or phone 120, the detection logic must be able to recognize when an expected command is received without wasting a lot of battery power on non-expected words and phrases.

#Text=[0033] Embodiments of the invention, as described in more detail herein, may perform a process that extracts sparse sound information directly from an analog signal that may be processed using ultra low power analog or mixed signal circuitry.
#Text=This process is referred to herein as "analog to information" (A2I).
